title: Wednesday, 27th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
PM

Look at the time

PM

Welcome

PM

I am so bad tempered this morning

11:04 am
PM

Not sure I'm in a fit state to do an ML session

PM

Anyway, people seem to be appearing on the right under their chosen handles

PM

Which is something

11:05 am
PM

I guess

PM

Have an Anglo American chart

PM

11:06 am
PM

That's about as volatile as my mood

PM

Leveraged to metals prices, as Bryce would say

PM

(Via Con -- jsut boring internal frustration stuff. will pull myself together)

11:07 am
BE

.... Well, that and year's first De Beers auction yesterday, which we didn't cover because of technicalities.

PM

(Soundbuy -- indeed)

BE

Not sure I can be bothered recapping, but it went okay. If you sell diamonds cheap then more people will buy them than if you well them more expensively. That was the key finding.

11:08 am
PM

Revelation

BE

Today, though, we have oil back testing $30 and yesterday feels like .... well ... yesterday.

BE

All the miners down.

11:09 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 647.30, down 18.2 (-2.73%), High: 662.10, Low: 635.40, Volume: 4.57m
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 366.50, down 11.5 (-3.04%), High: 376.70, Low: 358.00, Volume: 2.34m

Along with ......

11:09 am
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,399, down 22 (-1.55%), High: 1,420, Low: 1,386, Volume: 4.13m
BE

Spread against BG now down to about 2% incidentally.

BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 985.00, down 9.9 (-1.00%), High: 996.10, Low: 973.80, Volume: 4.40m
11:10 am
BE

Was trying to work out whether you'd have made money from short Shell, long BG (as in, the standard bid arb) .....

BE

.... and, probably not. But you wouldn't have lost as much as just holding either of them. So that's something.

BE

Anyway, since there's Anglo interest on the right, it's worth previewing its upcoming Q4

11:11 am
BE

Firstly, via a Deutsche argument on why it probably shouldn't call a rights issue.

BE

Basically, a third of the cash would be trapped in South Africa.

BE

(You could've read this yesterday. had the session worked. But it didn't so here it is now.)

11:12 am
BE

Many in the market, including ourselves, believe that without a material recovery in commodity prices over the next couple of years, Anglo may well be required to undertake a rights issue. This decision may be largely dependent on how much it is able to raise from its planned $2bn+ disposal programme.
But one issue that those calling for a rights issue do not appear to address is the impact that capital controls would have on proceeds raised from South African investors. With the company’s $13bn of net debt held outside of South Africa, this is particularly relevant.
Without dispensation from the SARB (SA Reserve Bank), which we do not expect to be forthcoming, any proceeds raised in SA will be constrained by same capital controls as operating cash flows i.e. funds repatriated may not exceed that of the Plc’s dividend. As such the 30% or so of the register in SA would not contribute to liquidity for debt reduction from any capital raise.

BE

There are theoretically ways round this, but in reality these would probably require implicit political support.
 Anglo could explain the restriction & commit to paying out a dividend straight back to shareholders for 30% of funds raised. This would have tax implications for some investors & could be politically tricky.
 SA shareholders could be asked to wave their rights. But this would only be acceptable if the discount on any rights issue was very modest, which given market conditions would appear unlikely.
 Anglo could undertake a share repurchases using SA funds and hold the shares in Treasury for future cancellation or in-specie dividends.
 Anglo could commit to re-starting its dividend programme earlier than operational cash flows would allow, but raising capital to fund dividends is clumsy.

BE

For a material improvement in the balance sheet we would expect any rights issue to target raising $4bn or so of proceeds. This would imply around a $6bn issue, with $1.8bn remaining in SA. This is slightly under the current balance in the revenue account in SA, from which any proposed capital repatriation needs to be drawn. From that point of view, even without any sales proceeds or dividends from Kumba or Amplats, Anglo would be able to pay out the $1.8bn in dividends without constraints. So not all bad news then…

11:13 am
BE

Deutsche's Anna Mulholland has been a believer in the idea of Anglo going ex South Africa

BE

Which does look a neat solution, though it's unknown whether it's a credible one.

BE

(@markopolo: yup, sorry, I meant from the first RNS a year ago.)

11:14 am
PM

raising capital to fund dividends is clumsy.

PM

Not just clumsy. It would be idiotic

BE

Yes, it rarely reflects well on management's ability to run a business.

11:16 am
BE

Anyway, in terms of the Q4 I think UBS summarises what to expect as well as anyone.

BE

we expect Anglo to provide a lot more detail on the plan to focus the group on ~20 "Priority 1" assets (down from 55 at end-2014) with its FY15 results on 16-Feb. We believe Anglo aims to exit Iron ore & Coal (~45% of group revenue) to become a later cycle play focused on Platinum, Diamonds, Copper & Nickel. We expect this restructuring to be the key catalyst for the stock near-term, with the Q4 production results on 28-Jan likely to be banal. We maintain a Neutral rating on the stock as we believe the execution risk is high and the balance sheet vulnerable in a lower for longer price environment. Anglo is scheduled to release its Q4 production report on 28-Jan at 7.00am (UK time). We expect production to be in line with guidance published at the Seminar on 8-Dec, with Kumba production -17% q/q as mgmt
move to the new mine plan (targeting $40/t CFR China cash breakeven), while Minas Rio & Barro Alto ramp up. Copper production is expected to be broadly flat q/q at Collahuasi & Los Bronces but overall production down following the sale of Norte in Q3. Anglo will provide Diamond sales (UBSe H2 8.6mcts with 5.5mct build in 2015) and provisionally priced copper
volumes. Press reports (e.g., Sunday Times 10-Jan) suggest the sale of Niobium & Phosphates is progressing well with 4+
parties interested and 1st round bids expected in mid-Feb; these assets generated $87m EBITDA in H1-15 and we estimate
NPV at $1.1bn or 6.3x H1 EBITDA (vs net debt of ~$13bn). In Dec-15, AAL flagged impairments of $3.7-4.7bn in H2-15 in
addition to $3.5bn in H1 (FY12-15 avge $4.2bn pa); while non-cash, these do not reflect well. We see the Rand weakness as a small positive (part offsetting price decline), and diamonds appear to be bottoming with cut prices up in Jan (albeit rough prices are still weak, inventories high, and realised prices will normalise down in 2016).

undefined
11:17 am
PM

Hey, i thought the Rabble would be thanking me for the quick buck they should have made on Just Eat!

PM

Session was down yesterday, but we fave clear advice int he apology post

PM

Just Sell

11:17 am
PM

Actually, it was Neil Campling of Aviate

PM

Let me dig out what he was saying

PM

And get the bloomberg grab

11:19 am
PM

PM

The 'decoupling' began nine months ago when GrubHub began to forecast declining returns. The size of GrubHub's preliminary 'beat' yesterday on Q4 numbers (see yesterday's note for details) was de minimis and the digestion of the same saw a 12% decline in the stock from pre-market levels to close at new all time lows of $18.71 (and well below the $26 IPO price).

PM

Much of the bull case for GrubHub and Just Eat is predicated on operational leverage from scale economics, perceived market share dominance, rising commission rates and slowing marketing costs. GrubHub needs to reinvest heavily to maintain market and mind share. With the entrance of Uber and Amazon in 2016 comes significant competition and the perceived inherent operational leverage is unlikely to deliver.

11:19 am
PM

Just Eat has made much of the virtue of its low capital spending, and hasn't built it's own delivery driver networks that some rivals offer. However, if Uber enters the UK market in 2016, as we expect, this new competitor would bring a similar unowned driver network with three key advantages over Just Eat: scale, brand awareness and logistical technology expertise. Just Eat's marketing budget is already high at ~25% of sales and this is only likely to increase in a defensive strategy to maintain growth/share. As such, the implied operational leverage is unlikely.

PM

For Just Eat the street expects 33% sales growth but a substantial 59% EBITDA growth in 2016. In 2017 sales slow to 24% growth but don’t worry EBITDA will grow at almost double the rate 42%. But will it, really? Which is why paying 8.2x EV/Sales, 45x P/E, 30x EV/EBITDA for Just Eat makes no sense to us. Short JE/ LN

BE

(@Bookworm: sorry, forgot about Anto. Will come back to it.)

11:19 am
PM

That's from yesterday

PM

today...

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 386.70, down 33.8 (-8.04%), High: 415.00, Low: 386.00, Volume: 2.90m
11:20 am
BE

Well, yes.

BE

Though the reason it's down 8% isn't necessarily that a seller stayed a seller.

BE

It's more that Morgan Stanley turned negative this morning.

11:21 am
BE

With what feels like a rather familiar argument, which is that food delivery is a rather crowded sector.

BE

It's a good note though. The central gist is that the market's being carved up by Deliveroo, Take Eat Easy and Quiqup .....

BE

As well as Amazon. And, potentially, Domino's.

11:22 am
BE

(Which has the best online ordering platform of the lot and it's always seemed a peculiarity that it doesn't white-label it.)

BE

Anyway, this is alll about the infrastructure suppliers.

BE

Their entry makes delivery workable for places that would otherwise find it too much of a fuss.

11:23 am

For example .......

BE

11:23 am

It's near Waterloo I think. It's halal.

BE

This is important because competition expands the supply.

BE

There are more places serving the same number of punters.

11:24 am
BE

As in, logistics-type delivery services add "premium casual", whereas Just Eat offers the ones with their own mopeds.

BE

So will people pay a premium to get Wagamama delivered, rather than take a chance on Supernoodle on the Rotherhithe Road?

BE

MOST's survey says that 18% of Just Eat users would.

11:24 am
BE

PM

Fascinating

BE

So, market fragments. Just Eat hits saturation for the .... saturated takeaways. Deliveroo and Amazon and whoever move in on the high-reputation high street places.

11:25 am
BE

Here's the cover page.

BE

Supply in UK restaurant food delivery is increasing, but not through
Just Eat. c.70% of dedicated takeaway restaurants are already on Just Eat.
Market supply growth is instead starting to come from dining restaurants
facilitated through platforms that do the delivery for them. We believe trends
on delivery will follow trends on the high street, and Just Eat's independent
takeaway restaurants stand to lose.

BE

We find concrete evidence of the expansion of alternative delivery
platforms. For example, our web data gathering shows that Deliveroo
restaurants represent c.12% of Just Eat's total and over 50% in certain cities.
Deliveroo was launched in 2013 and it only started expanding outside of
London in 2015. We envisage a scenario in which Just Eat does not have most
restaurants on its platform, losing the network effect which is its main barrier
to entry.

11:26 am
BE

Our new market model assumes a slight decline in Just Eat's TAM over
the next 5 years. While we still see Just Eat growing sharply in 2016 as online
penetration of diners rises from the current c.38% to 47%, we cut our forecasts
in the outer years to reflect the increasingly competitive environment.

BE

Our Underweight rating reflects long-term risks; short-term outlook
tougher to predict. In fact, we raise our 2016 EPS forecasts by 12% to factor
in higher UK order growth, earlier commission increases and FX. We think our
new forecasts better reflect investors' expectations for the year (which we see
as higher than consensus) but that the shares fail to reflect longer-term risks.
Our EPS 2017-20 forecasts increase 2-6% but on lower orders. Stronger for
longer execution is a clear risk to our call and could keep valuation elevated.

BE

Our new 390p price target is based on a SOTP approach with the UK
valued at 240p and other regions at a combined 150p. Our bull case of 590p
(UK 290p) reflects Just Eat's estimate of its revenue potential. Our bear case of
230p (UK 190p) assumes the shares derate to GrubHub's valuation.

11:26 am
BE

Which echoes a lot of what Campling says above.

undefined
BE

So. RBS's profit warning.

11:27 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 254.10, down 6.8 (-2.61%), High: 259.20, Low: 246.00, Volume: 11.11m
PM

Cleaning itself up. again

Cleaning itself up by warning on profits.

11:27 am
PM

How many years is it since the crunch?

BE

I've lost count. The question worth asking is, how many more resets are in the valuation?

BE

Which we'll move onto in a moment. But first, the headlines.

11:29 am
BE

£2bn of conduct and litigation charges in Q4

BE

A £1.6bn charge relating to its pension -- which is entirely out of leftfield, it seems. No previous nudge to expect that.

PM

sheesh

11:29 am
BE

BE

This'd be a bit unfortunate if you, for example, upgraded RBS to "buy" yesterday on the argument that there were very few nasty shocks left.

BE

Which is, of course, what UBS did.

11:30 am
BE

So let's cut to them first.

PM

They di

PM

d

11:31 am
BE

RBS has released a trading statement updating the market on four provisions it intends
to pass with 4Q15 results. In all these have TNAV per share at 350p (384p at 3Q, 382p
UBSe) and common equity tier 1 at 15.0% (16.2% at 3Q, 16.7% UBSe). The pension
fund charges, worth 0.7% of CT1 and 13p of TNAV, are a negative surprise to us. The
other provisions are earlier but no larger than we have in our numbers. Our view that
significant surplus capital will be delivered to shareholders is unchanged. RBS is trading
at 0.7x TNAV, 47p per share in capital over a 13% target CT1 level.

BE

RBS has announced plans to adjust TNAV and capital ratios for pension obligations
(£1.6bn), RMBS litigation provisions (£1.5bn) and PPI (£0.5bn). A £0.5bn private bank
goodwill write-down is TNAV and capital ratio neutral on our numbers. Our estimates
include non-operating charges of £9.6bn for RBS: litigation and legacy charges
(£4.6bn), PPI (£0.9bn), other conduct (£1bn) and restructuring (£3.1bn).

BE

Assuming PPI provision usage in line with 3Q15, PPI payout cover goes to ~25-30
months, potentially seeing RBS to the mid 2018 claim deadline proposed by the FCA
without further charge. Santander announced a €600m charge in 4Q15 today which
suggests a similar approach. This lends some credibility to the Sky News article (23 Jan
2016: Banks Face Fresh £5bn PPI Mis-Selling Bill) that suggested that UK majors will
provide for full estimated refunds to mid 2018 at 4Q15. LBG with a ~50% share of
provisions to end 3Q15, would provide £2.5bn, worth ~110bps of CT1. We have
£3.4bn in estimates for PPI for LBG to end 2020, unchanged today. Valuation: We
value RBS by sum-of-the-parts using peer group divisional multiples.

11:31 am
BE

The central argument UBS had yesterday, incidentally, was .....

BE

We estimate clean RBS would be worth 447p; the market is applying a £19bn discount for legacy issues – 63% of market cap

PM

hmm

11:32 am
PM

today's statement was unscheduled, right?

BE

Yes, it's a profit warning.

BE

Let's call it such, because it is. And RBS can shout at me after we've finished.

11:32 am
BE

It also provides some clarity on why a legacy issue discount is appropriate.

PM

Even if it's a £19bn discount

PM

This is ML etc

11:34 am
BE

RBC says:

BE

we consider the PPI and US RMBS litigation charges to be timing related rather than incremental and the ability to make further provisions
against the largest FHFA case arguably improves the outlook for capital return at year-end (we assume 10p DPS for FY 2016 to be announced in
February 2017). The pension accounting change is also a timing issue albeit not in forecasts. The lower pension deficit as a result of the up-front
contributions in Q1 2016 should lead to a lower Pillar 2A add-on and thus lower the hurdle rate for capital return. We would expect the reassessment
of the group’s Pillar 2A add-on in May 2016 to result in a lower add-on from the current £11bn (reduced from £12bn at the May 2015 assessment). We
have assumed no change to the £11bn add-on through to 2018 for the purposes of our excess capital assessment. No trading update was provided for
Q4 however the 4p residual decline in TBVPS (34p reduction in TBVPS to 350p of which 30p is from the announced charges) is in-line with our
estimates ex the dividend access share payment (we assumed £1.2bn charge would be booked in Q4 but now looks like it will be 2016). The CET1 ratio
is expected to be 15% (versus our 17.0% forecast) down from 16.2% proforma at end 30 September 2015.

BE

And Jefferies says:

11:35 am
BE

While further US RMBS and PPI charges have been largely expected by the
market, the pension change was something new and unfriendly near-term. Ultimately,
however, the pension changes should lower RBS's go-to CET1 ratio which is helpful for
capital repatriation expected in 1Q17.

BE

So that's that.

undefined
11:35 am
PM

Anything positive to share with the Rabble Bryce?

BE

That's a good question. My reflex answer is no. However .......

Aberdeen?

snap

11:39 am
BE

BE

Given it's in such a corner, it's odd that Martin Gilbert hasn't considered whether Aberdeen would fit better into a bigger group.

BE

Which, clearly, he hasn't. Because he's denied it. Loudly.

11:40 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

A weak trading update from Aberdeen revealing worse than expected group outflows of -£9.1bn, of which Equities accounted for -£6.3bn. This compares to Barclays forecast of -£6.5bn for the group and -£3bn from Equities. Management states that they have identified more cost saves than the £50m announced back in Nov but there is a lack of detail behind this. Management promises more granularity with the May interims but this is likely to frustrate, in our view. An improvement in flow momentum qoq was expected since the group lost -£12.7bn in the quarter to Sep with Equities representing -£7.9bn of this. But what is concerning is that the outflows are not just limited to the EM/Asia-Pac areas, where it could be excused as purely macro driven, but are more widespread. Of the -£6.3bn of Equities outflows only -£2.8bn is from EM/Asia-Pac vs -£3.5bn from Global Equities which is predominantly performance related. Aberdeen Solutions, their largest division with £127bn of AUM, lost a further -£3.3bn of outflows. Outlook statement reads realistically cautious – “considerable volatility continues” “despite day to day fluctuations in investor sentiment, the group remains focused on issues that they can control” but are “well placed to navigate difficult market conditions. The Aberdeen shares have underperformed in Jan 2016 falling -20% against the FTSE Allshare -6%. The shares are trading at 10x calendar 2016E PE.

BE

10x for Aberdeen. Cripes. Remember when it was three times that.

11:41 am
BE

Scarcity value, Asian tigers, superior fund performance, blah blah blah.

PM

yeah, i remember

PM

EM generally was going to bail out the West

11:42 am
BE

Peter Lenardos at RBC is off the call and not impressed.

BE

On the call, management indicated that they expect to see further withdrawals from sovereign wealth funds as they take risk off the table,
with the weak oil price being a motivating factor. Management indicated that at its height, sovereign wealth funds contributed 10% of total
AUM, which has now reduced to 2.5%. The company stated that despite reduced outflows in Q1/FY16 in equities (except for in Global where
outflows accelerated) on the prior quarter, it remains “too early to call a halt to outflows.” Higher outflows in Global came from both
sovereign wealth fund and segregated mandate redemptions. Management indicated that did not expect the pattern of redemptions to
affect the net management fee margin.

BE

Aberdeen noted that investment performance is “better” but that its needs a prolonged period of outperformance.
The underweight China position in particular is helping performance in the Emerging Markets fund. Management indicated that Aberdeen
remains committed to its investment style and still has no intention to change this.

11:43 am
PM

Goodness, it's weakened sharply after that call

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 235.00, up 2.2 (+0.95%), High: 245.10, Low: 232.90, Volume: 3.49m
PM

BE

Being underweight China isn't really a solution when you run an EM fund. More a sticking plaster on a severed leg.

BE

BE

Management stressed repeatedly that investor sentiment is not improving, noting that “sentiment was fragile and now is even more fragile,” given falls in China and volatile markets globally. Therefore according to management the impact on flows this quarter is “difficult to predict.”

11:44 am
BE

And to conclude:

BE

At the time of writing, Aberdeen’s share price is up by 2.5%, outperforming the FTSE 100 which is up by 20 bps. However our view remains that any enthusiasm should be short lived based on management’s weak flow outlook on the conference call. Further, while performance is showing some signs of improvement, it remains behind key benchmarks. Therefore, we remain confident in our negative stance.

BE

So that's the positive segment of today's show over.

11:44 am
undefined
BE

Kleinsclusive on Comparethemarket floating.

BE

http://news.sky.co...-huge-london-float

BE

The South African owners of Comparethemarket, Britain's biggest price comparison website, are considering a public listing that could value its parent company at several billion pounds.

BE

Which is interesting for a number of reasons.

(Moneysupermarket capped at £1.8bn for reference

Yeah, having a peer for Moneysupermarket would be useful.

PM

We've pondered aloud on how CompareTheMarket managed to win quite so much market share

BE

Based on perhaps the most effective cost-to-benefit advertising campaign in history.

BE

You have to hand it to them

tho always preferred the real version

A classic.

BE

Though the problem with advertising is that if you can do it to your competitors, your competitors can do it to you.

BE

Now, I'm not going to sub-edit Kleinman's copy, but he does say in about par four that Confused.com is privately owned.

(Mo -- you might be right)

No it's not. Admiral owns it.

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,725, up 28 (+1.65%), High: 1,725, Low: 1,693, Volume: 236.91k
11:51 am
BE

Which I note only because there's a bit of noise around Admiral right now.

PM

What kind of noise?

BE

Vague, to be clear.

11:52 am
BE

But some people are getting interested in the possible breakup values and suchlike

PM

hmm

BE

BE

Though clearly, operationally, you're in a tricky market. Premiums still under pressure, spurious claims for injury still an industry problem.

PM

Well, I'd just note that Shore are not with you on this

11:54 am
PM

They have some sector review out

PM

And it's v v negative

BE

I'm nowhere on this, to be clear. I'm just noting what I've heard.

11:54 am
PM

Sellers of Admiral, Direct Line Esure and Hastings

BE

Go on.

PM

he 2016 Shore Capital review of the non-life insurance sector, entitled “Back to basics” was published on Monday (25th) focusing on the prospects for both the UK personal motor insurance sector and the other quoted non-lifers. Please get in touch with your usual Shore Capital contact if you have not received a copy.

11:55 am
PM

I'll share the summary to save people the trouble

PM

Actually that's unfair

PM

Looks worth a proper read

11:55 am
PM

To understand what the FCA might do to this sector

PM

In today’s thought for the day we focus on the UK personal motor insurers. Although the UK personal motor insurance market is benefiting from rate increases, albeit at levels lower than we had expected, we view such upward rating moves as a lag indicator of a worrying level of increasing claims inflation. The latter reflects the multiplicative impact of rising claims frequency, which has emanated from an encouraging improvement in economic activity, together with growing claims severity, a consequence of the return of the insidious claims farming industry. The industry’s response in recent times has been to rely on the earnings stream from high margin add-on products together with ancillary and instalment income which, in many circumstances, the regulator has described as offering poor value for consumers. The FCA’s adoption of the ‘sunlight remedy’, which we describe in detail in the review, is likely to seriously disrupt the business models of the industry, put margins under intense pressure and, consequently, endanger the ratings underlying the quoted motor insurers.

PM

To this mix, we also consider the implications of the inexorable rise in liabilities associated with Periodic Payments Orders (the annuitisation of lump sum personal injury awards) which Solvency II may help to illuminate. Note that c12% of DLG’s liabilities at the end of 2015 are in respect of PPOs, which might explain its keenness to explore infrastructure assets. In addition, we examine the potential implications of autonomous (driverless) cars which could see the personal liability of a driver become the product liability of the car manufacturer…what then for ancillary income?

In valuing the above companies, we construct a SOTP based upon an appropriate price/NTAV for the underwriting part and a PER on the non-underwriting income. Such an approach delivers a SOTP of c1,230p for Admiral, c294p for DLG, c192p for esure and c152p for Hastings.

As a result, we reiterate our SELL recommendations on each of the motor insurers Admiral, Direct Line and esure and initiate coverage of Hastings with a similarly negative stance.

11:56 am
PM

Sunlight remedy

PM

This is about the FCA doing its own price comparisions

PM

Such as: https://www.fca.or...gs-sunlight-remedy

11:58 am
undefined
BE

11:58 am

Including us.

ha

12:00 pm
BE

Mild warning in the next quarter outlook, mostly on forex.

12:02 pm
BE

So we'll get a new iPhone in Q4, making incremental changes to the one introduced last Q4, and cash returns will be gradually crank up as the market becomes saturated.

BE

This is how capitalism works. I'm unclear on why it's so exciting.

BE

Anyway, Arm down a tad. Blame Apple. Or not. Not fussed.

12:02 pm
ARM Holdings PLC (ARM:LSE): Last: 991.50, down 23.5 (-2.32%), High: 1,005, Low: 986.50, Volume: 1.28m
PM

Oh Bryce, you are such a curmudgeon on Apple

PM

As Golly noted

12:03 pm
